Dear Ms. Carlton:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
6/28/2014, with an Exit conference on 7/10/2024. Due to the violations of applicable
licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months
after the staff member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written
evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
One of 18 employee records reviewed showed a new employee’s six month
performance evaluation was completed six days late.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2022, CAP approved 10/3/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12202 Policy and procedures.
(1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
procedures for all the areas of foster care services as
provided in R400.12203 to R 400.12214.
The agency requires an annual central registry clearance and ICHAT for all its
employees as a way to maintain compliance with staff qualification rules:
2

• One employee’s record showed the employee’s annual central registry
clearance due by 3/15/2024 was completed late on 5/8/2024.
• A second employee’s record showed the employee’s annual ICHAT due by
3/21/2024 was completed late on 3/29/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation must include a determination
and assessment of all the following:
(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as
determined by observation of, and interviews with, each
member of the household and each social service worker
who has had children placed in the home during the last
licensing period.
One of six open foster home records reviewed did not show documentation that all
workers who had children placed in the foster home during the licensing period had
been interviewed.
Repeat Violation Established
2023 Renewal; CAP approved 8/8/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed
corrective action plan, all social service workers who
have children placed in the home must be notified there
is a corrective action plan and what is required of the
foster parent in that plan.
One of six special evaluations reviewed did not show documentation that all workers
who had children placed in the home were notified of the corrective action plan and
what is required of the foster parents.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all
the following information:
(d) Findings of fact, based upon the evaluation.
3

One of six special evaluations reviewed did not show accuracy in its conclusion
related to finding of facts based on all interviews.

Three of six special evaluations reviewed showed documentation of MIC
(Maltreatment in Care) language and named the MIC worker in the report’s
methodology section, showing MIC/CPS (Child Protection Services) involvement in
the investigation.

Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms
must be completed for each type of meeting.

required time frames as out lined in the following table:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment

the case plan due date. Note: This FTM may be
combined with the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date. Permanent Ward Service
4

The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, must be
completed for every FTM.

8/5/2023-11/2/2023 updated service plan.
• A second record did not show documentation of an FTM for the child's
3/21/2024-6/18/2024 updated service plan.
• A third record did not show documentation of a DHS-1105 for an FTM
reported for 7/20/2023.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2022, CAP approved 10/3/2022.
FOM 722-D Treatment Plans.
Agreement and signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
Youth ages 14 and older.
Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record did not show documentation of the youth’s signature on the
child’s 5/9/2023-8/4/2023 treatment plan. Additionally, this child’s 8/5/2023-
11/2/2023 treatment plan was not signed by the youth, birth parent and foster
parent until 1/23/2024.
• A second record did not show documentation of the birth father’s signature
on the child’s 4/25/2023-7/23/2023 treatment plan until 10/21/2023.

5

Three of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of

Repeat Violation Established
2023 Renewal; CAP Approved 8/8/2023.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• R400.12327(6)(b) Special evaluation: The agency was apprised that its
letter advising foster parents that the special evaluation report is attached
shall not be dated prior to the date the special evaluation is approved.
• R400.12327(6) (c) Special evaluation: The agency was apprised it shall
consistently and more clearly show documentation of who interviewed
each interviewee.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• ADM 330 Quarterly Adoption Progress Report: The agency was
advised placing the quarterly reporting period timeframe at the top of the
quarterly progress report, may aid it in showing clearer documentation of
the accurate quarterly reporting period.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period. The corrective action plan was regarding the agency’s 2023
Renewal inspection. During that inspection 7 rule violations were established, 2 of
which were repeat violations from 2022. Two of the 2023 citations were repeat
violations this year. The number of individual cases cited this year for one of those
6

rules, R400.12324(2)(b), decreased from 3 of 6 to 1 of 6. The number of
individual cases cited related to the other rule/standard, FOM 801-3, increased
slightly from 2 of 6 to 3 of 6.
In the agency’s 2022 Interim inspection, 14 violations were established; 2 of which
were repeat violations this year. As it relates to those repeat violations, the
number of individuals cases cited deceased for one of the rules,
{R400.12212(3)(a)} from 4 of 15, to 1 of 18. The number of cases cited increased
slightly for the other rule/standard {FOM-722-D} from 2 of 8, to 3 of 6.
It is noteworthy, the agency’s compliance around its 2023 CAP has been positive,
despite the fact they had almost total staff turnover (14 new staff). The agency
provided sample proofs of emails, calendar reminders, and meeting agendas with
staff related to timeframes and review of the CAP. The agency will need to
continue its efforts to work on staff retention, and to maintain rule compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a Chief Administrator’s (CA) report dated 6/4/2024. The
administrator’s report indicated the agency experienced a difficult time maintaining
foster care and supervisory staff; as well as that a large amount of time was
needed to train the new staff. These matters were also discussed with the
administration during the entrance conference along with some efforts the agency
is trying around minimizing staff turnover. The CA indicated notwithstanding
worker turnover its CAP has relatively worked out well during this period. That a
number of the staff that had issues with rule compliance are no longer with the
agency. Additionally, the CA indicated varying compliance ranges related to
many of its KPIs (Key Performance Indicators) with medical and dental
completions being at 100% for its highest rating, and its lowest rating being 34%
for parent/worker contacts, due to parents not participating or not showing up for
visits.
The CA reported the agency will continue all efforts to maintain staff and to ensure
going and increased rule compliance.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted an annual 2024 budget and 9/30/2023 independent
financial audit. A review of these documents did not show any concerns.
Staff and Youth Interviews
In addition to my discussion with the chief administrator, licensee designee, foster
care program manager, licensing supervisor, human resource representative, and
a foster care supervisor at the entrance conference, I interviewed two foster care
workers, one adoption worker, one licensing worker. The staff interviewed
reported feeling supported by their supervisor and the administration. Other
themes that came out of interviews were that the agency has a very team-oriented
environment, where staff are checked on and offered lots of training. Additionally,
where the agency makes sure children feel comfortable in their placements; and
7

that suitable, appropriate child placement matches are made. Areas of growth or
improvements indicated were for continued recognition, support and an
understanding that foster care is a tough job; pay increases; more communication
around the agency’s corrective action plan’s progress and workers’ role in that;
more frequent check ins by supervisors with new workers in the beginning of
employment; and more meetings/opportunities to engage with staff in the agency’s
many other offices.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the agency's office was conducted and no concerns were
observed. The facility had adequate space and equipment for its staff; and files
were properly stored and secured.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
